column1: '''Lefnui''' was the westernmost of the many rivers of southern [[Gondor]]
column2: the Lefnui rose in the far west of the [[White Mountains]]. It followed an erratic course through the lands west of the hills of [[Pinnath Gelin]]
column3: until it emptied into the [[Bay of Belfalas]] through a long narrow firth.<ref>{{UT|Map}}</ref>  This river formed the eastern boundary of the [[Dr√∫waith Iaur]].<ref>{{UT|Druedain}}

column1: The Lefnui played little part in history
column2: though it was remembered by the [[Men]] of [[Rohan]]. When the [[Dunlendings]] invaded Rohan in {{TA|2758}}
column3: they were aided by Gondor's enemies from the south. These sea-going marauders landed at Lefnui's mouth on their mission to overrun and destroy the [[Rohirrim]]
column4: though they would eventually be defeated.<ref>{{App|Eorl}}</ref>

column1: ''Lefnui'' (also spelt ''Levnui'') is a [[Sindarin]] name. The name appears to mean "fifth".<ref>{{VT|42a}}
In the "working map" that [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] used while writing ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' this river had the name ''Lhefneg''.<ref>{{WR|3|XIV}}
